IFCONFIG_LOOPBACK.description: Specifies the loopback interface parameters to be configured when the stack is initialized, e.g. "ifname lo0", "inet 127.0.0.1/32","inet6 ::1/128","inet6 FF01::1/16". The following keywords are recognized. (1) "ifname" - specifies the name of loopback interface, e.g. "ifname eth0" (2) "inet" - specifies loopback IPv4 address and subnet, e.g. "inet 127.0.0.1/32". (3) "inet6" - specifies loopback IPv6 address and subnet, e.g. "inet6 ::1/128".

DHCPC_CLIENT_PORT.description: This parameter specifies the DHCP client port as a quoted string. For example: "68"

DHCPC_SERVER_PORT.description: This parameter specifies the DHCP server port as a quoted string. For example: "67"

DHCPC_REQ_OPTS.description: This parameter provides a comma separated list of DHCP option numbers that the DHCP client wants the server to provide. For example: "1,2,3,4"

DHCPC_CLIENT_ID.description: This parameter provides a string of characters that the DHCP client wants the server to identify it by. For example: "my_red_computer". If DHCPC_CLIENT_UUID is set "true", it should be defined similar to "4c:5f:00:ff".

DHCPC_CLIENT_UUID.description: This parameter determines if the DHCP client identifier type is uuid. If "false", the DHCPC_CLIENT_ID parameter is treated as a string. If "true", the DHCPC_CLIENT_ID parameter is treated as a character array.

DHCPC_RFC2131_INIT_DELAY.description: When set to "1", this parameter enables an RFC 2131 initialization delay identifier. To disable the identifier, set the value to "0".

DHCPC_RFC2131_EXP_BACKOFF.description: When set to "1", this parameter enables an RFC 2131 exponential back-off delay. To disable the delay, set the value to "0".

DHCPC_DISCOVER_RETRIES.description: This parameter sets the number of DHCP client retries.

DHCPC_OFFER_TIMEOUT.description: This parameter sets the DHCP offer time-out value in milliseconds.

DHCPC_IF_REQ_OPTS_LIST.summary: Interface specific option: parameter request list (55)
DHCPC_IF_REQ_OPTS_LIST.description: This parameter provides An interface name followed by a comma separated list of DHCP option numbers that the DHCP client wants the server to provide in the format "<ifparam>=<opts>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<opts>" is semicolon separated. For example: "eth0=1,2,3,4;eth1=2,3,4,5".

DHCPC_IF_CLIENT_ID_LIST.description: This parameter provides a string of characters that the DHCP client wants the server to identify it by in the format "<ifparam>=<id>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<id>" is semicolon separated. For example: "eth0=my_red_computer_eth0" or "eth0=my_red_computer_eth0;eth1=my_blue_computer_eth1".

DHCPC_INSTALL_OPTION_CALLBACK_HOOK.description: This parameter determines if the user-defined DHCP client callback routine, as specified by the DHCPC_OPTION_CALLBACK_HOOK macro, is installed. If FALSE, the DHCPC_OPTION_CALLBACK_HOOK configuration is not applicable.

DHCPC_INSTALL_REPLY_CALLBACK_HOOK.description: This parameter determines if the user-defined DHCP client callback routine, as specified by the DHCPC_REPLY_CALLBACK_HOOK macro, is installed. If FALSE, the DHCPC_REPLY_CALLBACK_HOOK configuration is not applicable.

DHCPC_OPTION_CALLBACK_HOOK.description: This user-defined DHCP option processing callback routine is called once for each option prior to IPDHCPC acting on the option. That is, this callback can be used to change the contents of the DHCP server reply (caution!). If not specified, the internal option callback routine is used. To install this callback routine, DHCPC_INSTALL_OPTION_CALLBACK_HOOK must also be set to TRUE.

DHCPC_REPLY_CALLBACK_HOOK.description: This callback is used to change the contents of the DHCP server reply (caution!). If not specified, the internal reply callback routine is used. To install this callback routine, DHCPC_INSTALL_REPLY_CALLBACK_HOOK must also be set to TRUE.

DHCPC_BOOTP_MODE.description: This parameter indicates that the DHCP client should operate as a BOOTP client only. That is, a DHCP "message type" option is not appended to requests. Set to "1" to enable, "0" to disable.

DHCPC_BOOT_FILENAME.description: This parameter specifies an optional file name to use in DHCP/BOOTP requests.

DHCPC_SERVER_HOSTNAME.description: Specifies an optional server host name to use in DHCP/BOOTP requests.

DHCPC_OPTION_HOSTNAME.description: This parameter defines the hostname option to use in requests.

DHCPC_OPTION_NETMASK.description: This parameter defines the subnet mask option to use in requests.

DHCPC_OPTION_VENDOR_CLASS_ID.description: This parameter defines the vendor class ID option.

DHCPC_OPTION_IPADDRESS_LEASE_TIME.description: This parameter provides an option that is used in a client request to allow the client to request a lease time for the IP address. A 0 value means no lease time is specified. The time is in units of seconds.

DHCPC_OPTION_VI_VENDOR_CLASS.summary: Global option: vendor identifying vendor class (124)
DHCPC_OPTION_VI_VENDOR_CLASS.description: This parameter defines the vendor identifying vendor class option. Expected format: enterprise_number1=data1;enterprise_number2=data2;... All data fields are specified in network byte order

DHCPC_REMOVE_EXISTING_ADDRESSES.description: This parameter is used to remove all unicast addresses from the interface before negotiation begins. Set to "1" to remove addresses or "0" to retain addresses.

DHCPC_REMOVE_LEASED_ADDRESS.description: This parameter is used to remove any leased address from the interface if the lease expires or DHCP is manually disabled. Set to "1" to remove addresses or "0" to retain addresses.

DHCPC_AUTO_DISABLE.description: This parameter is used to disable DHCP on the specified interface if another address is subsequently added using manual configuration. Set to "1" to turn on this feature, "0" to turn it off.

DHCPC_TTL.description: This parameter sets the time-to-live for DHCP packets. You can increase this value to interoperate with certain relay agents.

DHCPC_OPTION_MAX_MESSAGE_SIZE.summary: Global option: maximum DHCP message size (57)
DHCPC_OPTION_MAX_MESSAGE_SIZE.description: This parameter defines the maximum message size this client is prepared to accept. Per RFC 2131, the value must be at least 576.

DHCPC_OPTION_USER_SPECIFIED.description: This parameter defines a list of options and associated data that are not supported explicitly by other option configuration parameters. Expected format: "<option>=<option_data>". Each pair of "<option_number>=<option_data>" is semicolon separated. In addition, "<option_data>" must be specified in hex with network byte order. For example, "3=C0A80101;4=C0A80102" specifies a router option (3) with an address at 192.168.1.1 and a time server option (4) with an address at 192.168.1.2.

DHCPC_IF_INFORMATION_ONLY_LIST.description: This parameter specifies an interface that only receives information.

DHCPC_FLAGS_BIT_BROADCAST.description: This parameter sets the value of the broadcast bit.

DHCPC_TASK_PRIORITY.description: This parameter sets the task priority of the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol version 4 (DHCPv4) client network service task. Changing the value can have risks.

DHCPC_CFGFILE.description: This parameter provides the full pathname to a target file containing the DHCP client configuration parameters to be processed during system boot. To disable this capability, set to an empty string.

INET_IPAIP_IFNAME_LIST.description: This parameter specifies a space-separated list of interfaces that can configure a link-local IPv4 address. For example, "eth0 eth1".

INET_IPAIP_PROBE_WAIT.description: This parameter specifies the time (in seconds) the target waits before creating a link-local IPv4 address and checking it for uniqueness.

INET_IPAIP_PROBE_NUM.description: This parameter specifies the number of ARP requests the target sends to check a link-local address for uniqueness before it accepts the address.

INET_IPAIP_PROBE_MIN.description: This parameter specifies the minimum time (in seconds) to wait before sending the next probe. Auto IP sends the next probe between PROBE_MIN and PROBE_MAX seconds after the previous one.

INET_IPAIP_PROBE_MAX.description: This parameter specifies the maximum time (in seconds) to wait before sending the next probe. Auto IP sends the next probe between PROBE_MIN and PROBE_MAX seconds after the previous one.

INET_IPAIP_ANNOUNCE_WAIT.description: This parameter specifies the time (in seconds) that Auto IP waits before it starts to announce the address it selected. It does not defend the address if it hears another announcement during this period.

INET_IPAIP_ANNOUNCE_NUM.description: This parameter specifies the number of announcements for Auto IP to send.

INET_IPAIP_ANNOUNCE_INTERVAL.description: This parameter specifies the number of seconds between Auto IP announcements.

INET_IPAIP_MAX_CONFLICTS.description: This parameter specifies the maximum number of address collisions that Auto IP allows before it applies rate-limiting when it creates the next address.

INET_IPAIP_RATE_LIMIT_INTERVAL.description: This parameter specifies the delay between successive address regeneration attempts when the regeneration is rate-limited.

INET_IPAIP_DEFEND_INTERVAL.description: This parameter specifies the minimum interval between defensive ARPs.

INET_IPAIP_IFLIST_PROBE_WAIT.description: This parameter specifies the number of seconds a host waits before creating a link-local IPv4 address and checking it for uniqueness. This parameter can be specified for each interface specified in INET_IPAIP_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". For example, "eth0=1". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon.

INET_IPAIP_IFLIST_PROBE_NUM.description: This parameter specifies the number of times a link-local address is checked for uniqueness before being assigned. This parameter can be specified for each interface specified in INET_IPAIP_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". For example, "eth0=3". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon.

INET_IPAIP_IFLIST_PROBE_MIN.description: This parameter specifies the minimum number of seconds to wait before sending the next probe. This parameter can be specified for each interface specified in INET_IPAIP_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". For example, "eth0=1". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon.

INET_IPAIP_IFLIST_PROBE_MAX.description: This parameter specifies the maximum number of seconds to wait before sending the next probe. This parameter can be specified for each interface specified in INET_IPAIP_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". For example, "eth0=3". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon.

INET_IPAIP_IFLIST_ANNOUNCE_WAIT.description: This parameter specifies the time to wait (in seconds) before the selected IPv4 address is announced. The address is not defended if another announcement is heard during this period. The address is assigned to the interface when the announce period starts. This parameter can be specified for each interface specified in INET_IPAIP_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". For example, "eth0=2". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon.

INET_IPAIP_IFLIST_ANNOUNCE_NUM.description: This parameter specifies the number of announcements to send. This parameter can be specified for each interface specified in INET_IPAIP_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". For example, "eth0=2". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon.

INET_IPAIP_IFLIST_ANNOUNCE_INTERVAL.description: This parameter specifies the number of seconds between announcements. This parameter can be specified for each interface specified in INET_IPAIP_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". For example, "eth0=2". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon.

INET_IPAIP_IFLIST_MAX_CONFLICTS.description: This parameter specifies the maximum number of address collisions that are allowed before applying rate-limiting to the creation of the next address. This parameter can be specified for each interface specified in INET_IPAIP_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". For example, "eth0=10". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon.

INET_IPAIP_IFLIST_RATE_LIMIT_INTERVAL.description: This parameter specifies the delay between successive Auto IP attempts. This parameter can be specified for each interface specified in INET_IPAIP_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". For example, "eth0=60". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon.

INET_IPAIP_IFLIST_DEFEND_INTERVAL.description: This parameter specifies the minimum interval between defensive ARPs. This parameter can be specified for each interface specified in INET_IPAIP_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". For example, "eth0=10". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon.

INET_ENABLE_PROXY_ARP.description: When this parameter is set to "yes" the stack does proxy ARP for network routes tagged with the proxy arp flag.

INET_AUTO_PROXY_ARP.description: When this parameter is set to "yes" the stack automatically tags all interface address network routes as proxy arp.

INET_ACCEPT_SOURCE_ROUTE.description: When this parameter is set to "yes", the stack accepts source routed frames.

INET_IFLIST_ENABLE_PROXY_ARP.description: When this parameter is set to 1, the stack does proxy arping for network routes tagged with the proxy arp flag. This parameter can be configured on a per-interface basis in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". For example, "eth0=1". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon.

INET_IFLIST_AUTO_PROXY_ARP.description: When this parameter is set to 1, the stack automatically tags all interface address network routes as proxy arp. This parameter can be configured on a per-interface basis in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". For example, "eth0=1". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon.

RADVD_IFNAME_LIST.summary: Router advertisement daemon (radvd) interface name list
RADVD_IFNAME_LIST.description: This parameter specifies the name of the interface on which the radvd sends router advertisements and listens for router solicitation messages. The format is a space-separated list of interface names. For example, "eth0 eth1". The default is an empty list.

RADVD_IFLIST_ADV_MANAGED_FLAG.description: This parameter specifies the TRUE(=1)/FALSE(=0) value to be placed in the "Managed address configuration" flag field in the router advertisement. This parameter can be specified for each interface that is listed in RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon. For example, "eth0=0" or "eth0=0;eth1=0". Default: "0" (=FALSE).

RADVD_IFLIST_ADV_OTHER_CONFIG_FLAG.description: This parameter specifies the TRUE(=1)/FALSE(=0) value to be placed in the "Other stateful configuration" flag field in the router advertisement. This parameter can be specified for each interface that is listed in RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon. For example, "eth0=0" or "eth0=0;eth1=0". Default: "0" (=FALSE).

RADVD_IFLIST_ADV_LINK_MTU.description: This parameter specifies the value to be placed in MTU options sent by the router. A value of zero indicates that no MTU options are sent, which means that the MTU of the interface is used by all hosts. This parameter can be specified for each interface that is listed in RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon. For example, "eth0=0" or "eth0=0;eth1=0". Default: "0".

RADVD_IFLIST_ADV_REACHABLE_TIME.description: This parameter specifies the value to be placed in the Reachable Time field in the router advertisement messages sent by the router. A value of zero means it is unspecified (by this router). The value MUST be no greater than 3,600,000 milliseconds (1 hour). This parameter can be specified for each interface that is listed in RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon. For example, "eth0=0" or "eth0=0;eth1=0". Default: "0".

RADVD_IFLIST_ADV_RETRANS_TIMER.description: This parameter specifies the value to be placed in the Retrans Timer field in the router advertisement messages sent by this router. A value of zero means it is unspecified (by this router). This parameter can be specified for each interface that is listed in RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon. For example, "eth0=0" or "eth0=0;eth1=0". Default: "0".

RADVD_IFLIST_ADV_CUR_HOP_LIMIT.description: This parameter specifies the default value to be placed in the Cur Hop Limit field in the router advertisement messages sent by this router. The value should be set to the current diameter of the Internet. A value of zero means it is unspecified (by this router). This parameter can be specified for each interface that is listed in RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon. For example, "eth0=64" or "eth0=64;eth1=64". Default: "64".

RADVD_IFLIST_ADV_HA_FLAG.description: This parameter specifies the TRUE(=1)/FALSE(=0) value to be placed in the "home agent" flag field in the router advertisement. If this flag is set, it indicates that the router in question also serves as a home agent. This parameter can be specified for each interface that is listed in RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon. For example, "eth0=0" or "eth0=0;eth1=0". Default: "0" (=FALSE).

RADVD_IFLIST_ADV_INTERVAL_OPT.description: If this parameter is set to TRUE(=1), the router advertisement daemon appends a router advertisement interval option to the router advertisement. This option is specified in RFC 3775. This parameter can be specified for each interface that is listed in RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon. For example, "eth0=0" or "eth0=0;eth1=0". Default: "0" (=FALSE).

RADVD_IFLIST_ADV_HA_OPT.description: If this parameter is set to TRUE(=1), the router advertisement daemon appends a home agent information option to its router advertisement. This parameter can be specified for each interface that is listed in RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon. For example, "eth0=0" or "eth0=0;eth1=0". Default: "0" (=FALSE).

RADVD_IFLIST_HA_OPT_LIFETIME.description: This parameter specifies the home agent's lifetime (in seconds),                 ranging between 1 and 65535. This parameter can be specified                 for each interface that is listed in RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the                 form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is                 separated by a semicolon. For example, "eth0=18000" or                 "eth0=18000;eth1=18000". The default value is the value of                 RADVD_IFLIST_ADV_DEFAULT_LIFETIME expressed in seconds.

RADVD_IFLIST_HA_OPT_PREFERENCE.description: This parameter specifies the home agent's preference. This                 parameter can be specified for each interface that is listed in                 RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair                 of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon. For example,                 "eth0=0" or "eth0=0;eth1=0". Default: "0".

RADVD_IFLIST_HA_OPT_MOBILE_ROUTER.summary: Mobile IP home agent mobile router support option
RADVD_IFLIST_HA_OPT_MOBILE_ROUTER.description: This parameter specifies whether or not the home agent has mobile router support. If not specified, Dynamic Home Agent Address Discovery (DHAAD) for Mobile Routers does not succeed. This parameter can be specified for each interface that is listed in RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon. For example, "eth0=0" or "eth0=0;eth1=1". The default value is RADVD_IFLIST_HA_OPT_MOBILE_ROUTER set to "0".

RADVD_IFLIST_MIN_RTR_ADV_INTERVAL.description: This parameter specifies the minimum time allowed (in seconds) between sending unsolicited multicast router advertisements from the interface. MUST be no less than 30 milliseconds and no greater than 75% of MaxRtrAdvInterval. The interval limitations are set according to RFC 3775. This parameter can be specified for each interface that is listed in RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon. For example, "eth0=200000" or "eth0=200000;eth1=200000". Default: "200000" (MaxRtrAdvInterval / 3).

RADVD_IFLIST_MAX_RTR_ADV_INTERVAL.description: This parameter specifies the maximum time (in seconds) allowed between sending unsolicited multicast router advertisements from the interface. MUST be no less than 70 milliseconds and no greater than 1800000 seconds. This parameter can be specified for each interface that is listed in RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon. For example, "eth0=600000" or "eth0=600000;eth1=600000". Default: "600000".

RADVD_IFLIST_ADV_DEFAULT_LIFETIME.description: This parameter specifies the value (in seconds) to be placed in the Router Lifetime field of router advertisements sent from this interface. This parameter must be set to either zero or between 1000 and 9000000 milliseconds. A value of zero indicates that the router is not to be used as a default router. This parameter can be specified for each interface that is listed in RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon. For example, "eth0=1800000" or "eth0=1800000;eth1=1800000". Default: 3 * MaxRtrAdvInterval, but at least 1000 milliseconds.

RADVD_IFLIST_ADV_PREFIX.description: This parameter specifies a list of prefixes to add to the router advertisement messages. The elements are an identifier for the prefix, not the actual prefix. This parameter can be specified for each interface that is listed in RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon. For example, "eth0=6to4net" or "eth0=6to4net;eth1=devnet". The default value is an empty list.

RADVD_IFLIST_PREFIX.description: This parameter specifies the prefix and prefix length. The prefix length must be between 1 and 127 and must be 64 for Ethernet if it is used for automatic address configuration. This parameter can be specified for each interface that is listed in RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon. For example, "eth0.prefix.6to4net=2002:0a01:0264::/64" or "eth0.prefix.6to4net=2002:0a01:0264::/64;eth1.prefix.devnet=                 2002:a01:201:1::/64". Default: "" (not specified).

RADVD_IFLIST_MIN_DELAY_BETWEEN_RAS.summary: Minimum delay between solicited router advertisements
RADVD_IFLIST_MIN_DELAY_BETWEEN_RAS.description: This parameter specifies the minimum delay between solicited router advertisements. If not specified, the value defaults to MinRtrAdvInterval. This configuration variable is defined in RFC 3775 and can be specified for each interface that is listed in RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon. For example, "eth0=200000" or "eth0=200000;eth0=200000". Default: "200000" (MinRtrAdvInterval).

RADVD_IFLIST_PREFIX_ADV_ONLINK_FLAG.description: This parameter specifies the value to be placed in the On-Link flag field in the prefix information option. This parameter can be specified for each interface that is listed in RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon. For example, "eth0.prefix.6to4net=1" or "eth0.prefix.6to4net=1;eth1.prefix.devnet=1". Default: 1 (TRUE).

RADVD_IFLIST_PREFIX_ADV_AUTONOMOUS_FLAG.description: This parameter specifies the value to be placed in the Autonomous flag field in the prefix information option. This parameter can be specified for each interface that is listed in RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon. For example, "eth0.prefix.6to4net=1" or "eth0.prefix.6to4net=1;eth1.prefix.devnet=1". Default: 1 (TRUE).

RADVD_IFLIST_PREFIX_ADV_RTR_ADDR_FLAG.description: This parameter specifies the value to be placed in the Router Address flag field in the prefix information option. This indicates that the specified prefix is also a complete, global address for the router. This flag is specified in RFC 3775 and can be specified for each interface that is listed in RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon. For example, "eth0.prefix.6to4net=0" or "eth0.prefix.6to4net=0;eth1.prefix.devnet=0". Default: 0 (FALSE).

RADVD_IFLIST_PREFIX_ADV_VALID_LIFETIME.description: This parameter specifies the value (in seconds) to be placed in the Valid Lifetime field in the prefix information option. The designated value of all is (-1) which represents infinity. This parameter can be specified for each interface that is listed in RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon. For example, "eth0.prefix.6to4net=-1" or "eth0.prefix.6to4net=-1;eth1.prefix.devnet=-1". Default: "-1" (infinite).

RADVD_IFLIST_PREFIX_ADV_PREFERRED_LIFETI.description: This parameter specifies the value (in seconds) to be placed in the Preferred Lifetime field in the prefix information option. The designated value of all is (-1) which represents infinity. This parameter can be specified for each interface that is listed in RADVD_IFNAME_LIST in the form of "<ifparam>=<value>". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is separated by a semicolon. For example, "eth0.prefix.6to4net=-1" or "eth0.prefix.6to4net=-1;eth1.prefix.devnet=-1". Default: "-1" (infinite).

RADVD_IFLIST_PREFIX_ADV_VALID_LIFETIME_D.description: This parameter enables or disables the valid lifetime auto-decrementing feature. For example, "eth0.prefix.6to4net.AdvValidLifetimeDecrement=1". The default is "0" (no auto-decrement).

RADVD_IFLIST_PREFIX_ADV_PREFERRED_LIFETI.description: This parameter enables or disables the preferred lifetime auto-decrementing feature. For example, "eth0.prefix.6to4net.AdvValidLifetimeDecrement=1". The default is "0" (no auto-decrement).

RADVD_TASK_PRIORITY.description: This parameter sets the task priority of the router advertisement daemon (radvd) network service task. Changing the value can have risks.

L2TP_VERSION_2_ENABLE.description: This parameter enables the L2TP protocol version 2 as defined in RFC2661.

L2TP_VERSION_3_ENABLE.description: This parameter enables the L2TP protocol version 3 as defined in RFC3931.

L2TP_TASK_PRIORITY.description: This parameter sets the task priority of the layer 2 tunneling protocol (L2TP) network service task. Changing the value may have risks.

IPNET_MAX_INPUT_PKTS.description: This parameter specifies the maximum number of packets that can be stored in the packet input queue.

IPNET_BUSY_TASK_PRIORITY.description: This parameter specifies the priority for the network task when the network task is under heavy CPU-load. This priority should normally be lower than NET_TASK_DEFAULT_PRIORITY and it should normally be equal to or lower (higher numeric value) than all performance critical network applications.

IPNET_REASSEMBLY_TIMEOUT.description: This parameter specifies the number of seconds IPNET keeps incomplete datagram fragments in the reassembly list before discarding them. The default is 60 seconds per RFC 2460.

IPNET_MEMORY_LIMIT.description: This parameter specifies the maximum amount of dynamic memory the stack is allowed to use.

IPNET_DST_CACHE_LIMIT.description: This parameter specifies the maximum amount of destination cache number the stack is allowed to use. When set to 0, there is no limit (default).

IPNET_MAX_REASSEMBLY_LIST_LEN.description: This parameter specifies the maximum number of partially reassembled fragmentation chains that are allowed to be present at any given time. The oldest fragmentation list is dropped if this limit is exceeded.

IPNET_MAX_DGRAM_FRAG_LIST_LEN.description: This parameter specifies the maximum number of fragments an individual IP-datagram is allowed to consist of. The partly reassembled IP-datagram is dropped if this limit is exceeded.

IPNET_SLAB_DESC_0.description: This parameter specifies descriptor 0 in the slab cache configuration array. The fields are: mtu - The maximum MTU this buffer can hold. flags - The IPCOM_SLAB_F_xxx flags for this buffer. empty_lim - Maximum empty slabs in the cache before quick garbage collection.

IPNET_SLAB_DESC_1.description: This parameter specifies descriptor 1 in the slab cache configuration array. The fields are: mtu - The maximum MTU this buffer can hold. flags - The IPCOM_SLAB_F_xxx flags for this buffer. empty_lim - Maximum empty slabs in the cache before quick garbage collection.

IPNET_SLAB_DESC_2.description: This parameter specifies descriptor 2 in the slab cache configuration array. The fields are: mtu - The maximum MTU this buffer can hold. flags - The IPCOM_SLAB_F_xxx flags for this buffer. empty_lim - Maximum empty slabs in the cache before quick garbage collection.

IPNET_SLAB_DESC_3.description: This parameter specifies descriptor 3 in the slab cache configuration array. The fields are: mtu - The maximum MTU this buffer can hold. flags - The IPCOM_SLAB_F_xxx flags for this buffer. empty_lim - Maximum empty slabs in the cache before quick garbage collection.

IPNET_SLAB_DESC_4.description: This parameter specifies descriptor 4 in the slab cache configuration array. The fields are: mtu - The maximum MTU this buffer can hold. flags - The IPCOM_SLAB_F_xxx flags for this buffer. empty_lim - Maximum empty slabs in the cache before quick garbage collection.

IPNET_SLAB_DESC_5.description: This parameter specifies descriptor 5 in the slab cache configuration array. The fields are: mtu - The maximum MTU this buffer can hold. flags - The IPCOM_SLAB_F_xxx flags for this buffer. empty_lim - Maximum empty slabs in the cache before quick garbage collection.

IPNET_INTERCOM_CONGESTION_LIMIT.summary: Congestion limit for relaying signals between stack instances
IPNET_INTERCOM_CONGESTION_LIMIT.description: This parameter specifies the number of signals in the queue of signals that have been relayed to a stack instance by other instances, at which the relay queue (intercom) is considered congested. When congested, some signals corresponding to certain packets to be relayed can be dropped instead. At present this applies only to TCP initial SYN segments only.

INET_MIN_MTU_SIZE.description: This parameter sets the minimum MTU size, meaning the smallest path MTU expected in any route. All Internet routers should be able to handle 576 octets. This value is used by some Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) messages that include data from the packet that caused an ICMP message to be sent.

INET_BASE_HOP_LIMIT.description: This parameter specifies the default value for the time-to-live (TTL) field for IPv4 unicast datagram packets.

INET_SEND_GRATUITOUS_ARP.description: This parameter specifies whether or not to send a gratuitous ARP when addresses are added.

INET_DELETE_ADDR_ON_DUPLICATE_DETECT.description: When enabled, this parameter automatically removes a configured IPv4 address upon duplicate address detection (gratuitous ARP).

INET_MAX_PKTS_PENDING.description: This parameter specifies the maximum number of packets that can be waiting before IPv4 to link layer resolution is finished.

INET_MAX_UNICAST_SOLICIT.description: This parameter specifies the maximum number of unicast ARP request messages that the stack should send before starting to use multicast solicits.

INET_MAX_MULTICAST_SOLICIT.description: This parameter specifies the maximum number of ARP request messages the stack should resend before staring to use application probes.

INET_MAX_APP_SOLICIT.description: This parameter specifies the number of resolve messages that are sent to routing/netlink sockets if the ARP probes fail (or are disabled).

INET_BASE_REACHABLE_TIME.description: This parameter specifies the duration, in seconds, that an entry in the Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) cache is in a reachable state.

INET_BASE_RETRANSMIT_TIME.description: This parameter specifies the number of seconds to wait between retransmits.

INET_DELAY_FIRST_PROBE_TIME.description: This parameter specifies the duration, in seconds, to wait for a stale Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) entry to become reachable before forcing a probe. Packets are sent using the stale entry during this time.

INET_NBR_CACHE_TO_LIVE_TIME.description: This parameter specifies the duration, in seconds, that can pass before a stale entry in the ARP cache is deleted.

INET_DST_CACHE_TO_LIVE_TIME.description: This parameter specifies the number of seconds an entry is kept in the destination cache. The destination cache contains forwarding information base (FIB) entries created in response to redirect and need-frag Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) messages.

INET_NBR_MIN_RANDOM_FACTOR.description: This parameter specifies the minimum value of a random factor.

INET_NBR_MAX_RANDOM_FACTOR.description: This parameter specifies the maximum value of a random factor.

INET_DISABLE_BROADCAST_FWD.description: This parameter controls the forwarding of broadcasts. Set to 1 to disable the forwarding of broadcasts or set to 0 to enable.

INET_ICMP_RATE_LIMIT_BUCKET_SIZE.description: This parameter specifies the number of Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) messages that the stack is allowed to send in the interval specified by INET_ICMP_RATE_LIMIT_INTERVAL.

INET_ICMP_RATE_LIMIT_INTERVAL.description: This parameter sets the Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) rate limit interval in milliseconds.

INET_ICMP_REDIRECT_SEND.description: Set this parameter to 2 if the stack should send a redirect and forward the original message (default). Set this parameter to 1 if the stack should send a redirect but discard the original message. Set this parameter to 0 if the stack should not send a redirect but should still forward the original message. Set this parameter to -1 if the stack should not send a redirect but should discard the original message.

INET_ICMP_REDIRECT_RECEIVE.description: To accept and process redirect messages, do NOT set this parameter to 0.

INET_ICMP_IGNORE_ECHO_REQ.description: This parameter controls if the stack should answer to Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) echo request messages. When set to 0, the stack answers echo requests.

INET_ICMP_IGNORE_TIMESTAMP_REQ.description: This parameter controls if the stack should answer to Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) timestamp request messages. When set to "0", the stack answers timestamp requests.

INET_ICMP_SEND_TIME_EXCEEDED.description: If the stack should send time exceeded messages, do NOT set this parameter to 0.

INET_ICMP_SEND_DST_UNREACHABLE.description: If the stack should send destination unreachable messages, do NOT set this parameter to 0.

INET_ICMP_IGNORE_BROADCAST.description: If the network stack should ignore Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) requests from broadcast addresses, set this parameter to 1.

INET_UDP_CHECKSUM.description: Set this parameter to 0 to disable UDP checksum for IPv4.

INET_RANDOM_IP_ID.description: Set this parameter to 1 to enable random IP ID for IPv4.

INET6_MIN_MTU_SIZE.description: This parameter specifies the smallest path MTU expected in any route. All Internet routers should be able to handle 1280 octets. This value is used by some Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) messages that include data from the packet that caused an ICMP message to be sent.

INET6_BASE_HOP_LIMIT.description: This parameter specifies the default hop limit for IPv6 packets.

INET6_MAX_PKTS_PENDING.description: This parameter specifies the number of packets that can be waiting for IPv6 to link layer resolution to finish.

INET6_MAX_UNICAST_SOLICIT.description: This parameter specifies the number of unicast neighbor discovery messages that should be sent for a neighbor discovery entry update before starting to use multicast solicit.

INET6_MAX_MULTICAST_SOLICIT.description: This parameter specifies the number of neighbor discovery messages that should be present before starting to use application solicit. Setting this parameter to a non-zero value causes IPv6 ready tests to fail. Change this value only if needed.

INET6_MAX_APP_SOLICIT.description: This parameter specifies the number of resolve messages that are sent to routing/netlink sockets if the neighbor discovery probe fails (or is disabled).

INET6_DAD_TRANSMITS.summary: Number of duplicate address detection transmits
INET6_DAD_TRANSMITS.description: This parameter specifies the number of times the node should test the address for uniqueness before assigning it to the interface. (To turn off duplicate address detection, set this value to 0).

INET6_BASE_REACHABLE_TIME.description: This parameter specifies the duration, in seconds, that an entry in the Neighbor Discovery Protocol (NDP) cache is in a reachable state.

INET6_BASE_RETRANSMIT_TIME.description: This parameter specifies the number of seconds to wait between retransmits.

INET6_DELAY_FIRST_PROBE_TIME.description: This parameter specifies the duration, in seconds, to wait for a stale neighbor discovery entry to become reachable before forcing a probe. Packets are sent using the stale entry during this time.

INET6_NBR_CACHE_TO_LIVE_TIME.description: This parameter specifies the duration, in seconds, that can pass before a stale entry in the neighbor cache is deleted.

INET6_DST_CACHE_TO_LIVE_TIME.description: This parameter specifies the duration, in seconds, that can pass before an entry in the destination cache is deleted. This lifetime is used on entries created as a response to redirect and need frag Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) messages.

INET6_ROUTER_LIFETIME.description: This parameter specifies the number of seconds this router can be used as a gateway after a router advertisement is sent. This parameter is only used when configured as a router.

INET6_ICMP_RATE_LIMIT_BUCKET_SIZE.description: This parameter specifies the number of ICMPv6 messages the stack is allowed per Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) rate limit interval which is measured in milliseconds.

INET6_ICMP_RATE_LIMIT_INTERVAL.description: Use this parameter to set the Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) rate limit interval. The interval is measured in milliseconds. To disable the rate limiter, set this value to 0.

INET6_ICMP_REDIRECT_SEND.description: Set this parameter to 2 if a redirect should be sent and the original message should be forwarded (default). Set this parameter to 1 if a redirect should be sent but the original message should be discarded. Set this parameter to 0 if no redirect should be sent but the original message should be forwarded. Set this parameter to -1 if no redirect should be sent and the original message should be discarded.

INET6_ICMP_REDIRECT_RECEIVE.description: To accept and process redirect messages, set this parameter to != 0.

INET6_ICMP_IGNORE_ECHO_REQ.description: If you want the stack to answer echo requests, set this parameter to 0.

INET6_ICMP_SEND_TIME_EXCEEDED.description: If the stack should send time exceeded messages, set this parameter to != 0.

INET6_ICMP_SEND_DST_UNREACHABLE.description: Is the stack should send destination unreachable messages, set this parameter to != 0.

INET6_ACCEPT_RTADV.description: To enable processing of router advertisement messages, set this parameter to 1. To disable this option, set to 0.

INET6_AUTO_CONFIG.description: To enable IPv6 address auto configuration, set this parameter to 1. To disable this option, set this value to 0.

INET6_ADD_AUTONOMOUS_ADDR.description: When this parameter is set to "yes", this node creates addresses from router advertisement messages.

INET6_RTHDR0.description: Use this parameter to enable or disable processing of routing header type 0. Due to potential security problems, this option is disabled by default.

INET6_DISCARD_UDP_WITH_ZERO_CHECKSUM.summary: Discard UDP packet with zero checksum for IPv6
INET6_DISCARD_UDP_WITH_ZERO_CHECKSUM.description: To discard ipv6 UDP packet with zero checksum, set this parameter to 1. To accept ipv6 UDP packet with zero checksum set this value to 0.

INET6_ENABLE_PRIVACY_EXTENSONS.description: Use this parameter to enable or disable privacy extensions.

INET6_TEMP_VALID_LIFETIME.description: This parameter specifies the maximum lifetime, in seconds, of temporary addresses. The default value is 1 week.

INET6_TEMP_PREFERRED_LIFETIME.description: This parameter specifies the maximum preferred time, in seconds, of temporary addresses. The default value is 1 day.

INET6_REGEN_ADVANCE.description: This parameter specifies the number of seconds before a current temporary address becomes non-preferred and a new address is generated. The RFC recommends a default value of 5 seconds. However, this implementation uses 30 seconds as the default value.

INET6_IFLIST_ENABLE_PRIVACY_EXTENSONS.description: Use this parameter to enable or disable privacy extensions. This parameter can be configured on a per-interface basis using a form of "<ifparam>=<value>". For example, "eth0=1". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" values is semicolon separated.

INET6_IFLIST_TEMP_VALID_LIFETIME.description: This parameter specifies the maximum lifetime, in seconds, of temporary addresses. The default value is 1 week. This parameter can be configured on a per-interface basis using a form of "<ifparam>=<value>". For example, "eth0=604800". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is semicolon separated.

INET6_IFLIST_TEMP_PREFERRED_LIFETIME.description: This parameter specifies the maximum preferred time, in seconds, for temporary addresses. The default value is 1 day. This parameter can be configured on a per-interface basis using a form of "<ifparam>=<value>". For example, "eth0=86400". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is semicolon separated.

INET6_IFLIST_REGEN_ADVANCE.description: This parameter specifies the number of seconds before the current temporary address goes non-preferred and a new address is generated. The RFC recommends a default value of 5 seconds. However, this implementation uses 30 seconds as the default value. This parameter can be configured on a per-interface basis using a form of "<ifparam>=<value>". For example, "eth0=30". Each pair of "<ifparam>=<value>" is semicolon separated.

IPNAT_ICMP_MAPPING_TIMEOUT.description: This parameter specifies the timeout value in seconds until an Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) mapping expires.

IPNAT_UDP_MAPPING_TIMEOUT.description: This parameter specifies the timeout value in seconds until a UDP mapping expires.

IPNAT_TCP_MAPPING_TIMEOUT.description: This parameter specifies the timeout value in seconds until a TCP mapping expires.

IPNAT_OTHER_MAPPING_TIMEOUT.description: This parameter specifies the timeout value in seconds until other mappings expire.

IPNAT_MAX_MAPPING.description: This parameter specifies the maximum number of active NAT mappings.

IPNAT_AUTOPORT_START_INTERVAL.description: This parameter specifies the start of the automatically NATed ports interval.

IPNAT_AUTOPORT_END_INTERVAL.description: This parameter specifies the end of the automatically NATed ports interval.

TCP_CONN_TIMEOUT.description: This parameter defines the number of seconds IPNET tries to create a TCP connection before giving up.

TCP_MAX_RETRANSMITS.description: This parameter specifies the maximum number of times a TCP segment is resent before giving up with an IPTCP_ERRNO_ETIMEDOUT error. Exponential back off is applied before each resend (the maximum time between two resends is 1 minute).

TCP_MSL.description: TCP sockets that enter the TIME_WAIT state are in that state for 2 times this value. Per RFC 793, this value should be 120 sec (2 minutes), but most TCP/IP stacks (including this implementation) set this value to 30 seconds.

TCP_DELAY_ACK_TIME.description: This parameter defines the number of milliseconds a receiver will reply to a peer with a delay ACK.

IPTCP_MAX_RETRAMSMITS_IN_TRANSIENT.description: This parameter specifies the maximum number of resend attempts to use when the number of sessions in the transient state exceeds the transient threshold set with iptcp.TransientTresh.

TCP_IMMEDIATE_ACK_FOR_PSH.description: When this parameter is set to 1, there is an immediate ACK reply for PSH.

IPTCP_MAX_TRANSIENT.description: This parameter specifies the maximum number of sessions that can be in a transient state. Once the value is reached, the session with the longest transient state period is dropped and the session is set to the CLOSED state. The session is then removed from the list of sessions in a transient state.

IPTCP_TRANSIENT_THRESH.description: This threshold value refers to the number of sessions in a transient state. When this threshold is exceeded, the number of resend attempts is reduced to a value set by iptcp.MaxRetransmitsTransientStates.

TCP_MAX_MSS.description: This parameter specifies the largest maximum segment size (MSS) that TCP will ever suggest. The actual MSS suggested can be smaller than this number if it is depending on the MTU for the interface. To use the largest MSS allowed by the MTU, set this parameter to 0.

TCP_USE_TIMESTAMP.description: This parameter determines if the timestamp option should be included in all segments for peers that support it. If the timestamp option should never be used, set the parameter to 0.

TCP_USE_RFC1122_URGENT_DATA.description: Set this parameter to "1" to use urgent data as described in RFC 1122. Set this parameter to "0" to use urgent data as described in RFC 793. In general, set this value to 0 because that is how most stacks work. To successfully pass Ixia ANVL TCP-CORE group 19 tests, it must be set to 1.

TCP_SEGMENT_MULTIPLIER.description: This parameter specifies the size multiplier that is used on outgoing segments when the outgoing interface supports TCP segmentation offload. Higher values generally give better performance, but any factor higher than 2 is not guaranteed to work on all network cards.

TCP_LAND_ATTACK_PROTECTION.description: Use this parameter to enable or disable LAND attack protection on TCP. Set the value to 1 to prevent LAND attacks on a TCP implementation.

TCP_ALLOW_ZERO_WINDOW.description: Use this parameter to enable or disable acceptance of the peer window being set to zero in the ACK of the SYN/ACK. An attacker can use zero window to keep the node persistent for an extended time.

TCP_ALLOW_TINY_WINDOW.description: Use this parameter to enable or disable acceptance of the peer window being set to a value less that one maximum segment size (MSS) in the ACK of the SYN/ACK. An attacker can use a tiny window to keep the node persistent for an extended time. Enabling this option can sometimes cause connection trouble in environments that contain traffic shapers that modify the peer windows of TCP segments. This is why it is allowed by default.

TCP_PERSIST_TMO.description: This parameter specifies the maximum duration, in seconds, a peer can keep announcing a receive window of size zero. The default value is "0" which means "infinite".

TCP_CLAMP_MSS.summary: Clamp MSS for session that goes through a gateway
TCP_CLAMP_MSS.description: This parameter specifies the maximum MSS that is used for TCP sessions to nodes that are not link local. The default value is 0 which means that path MTU is used to calculate the MSS.

TCP_DEFAULT_BACKLOG_SIZE.summary: Size of the default listen backlog
TCP_DEFAULT_BACKLOG_SIZE.description: This parameter specifies the default backlog size. This is the value that is used when 0 is passed as the second argument to listen( ).

TCP_KEEP_IDLE.description: This parameter specifies the default time a TCP connection must be idle before the first keep-alive packet is sent (in seconds).

TCP_KEEP_INTVL.description: This parameter specifies the time between each keep-alive probe.

TCP_KEEP_CNT.description: This parameter specifies the number of unsuccessful keep-alive probes that are sent before dropping the connection.

TCP_USE_RFC6528_SECURE_ISN.summary: Use RFC6528 secure Initial Sequence Number (ISN)
TCP_USE_RFC6528_SECURE_ISN.description: The secure ISN described in RFC 6528 is used in a TCP three-way handshake, which mitigates sequence number guessing attacks. To use secure ISN, set this parameter to "1". Otherwise, set to "0".

TCP_FORCE_IM_ACK_CNT.description: This parameter defines the number of delayed ACKs that can be received before transmission of an immediate ACK is forced.

TCP_CHALLENGE_ACK_CNT.description: This parameter defines the number of challenge ACKs that is used to reply to potential 'Blind Reset' or 'Blind Data Injection' Attack.

TCP_MIN_RTO.description: This parameter defines the minimum value of tcp retransimission timeout time.

IPCOM_SYSLOGD_DEFAULT_PRIORITY.description: Choose one of the following: IPCOM_LOG_EMERG, IPCOM_LOG_CRIT, IPCOM_LOG_ERR, IPCOM_LOG_WARNING, IPCOM_LOG_NOTICE, IPCOM_LOG_INFO, IPCOM_LOG_DEBUG, IPCOM_LOG_DEBUG2

IPCOM_SYSLOGD_QUEUE_MAX.description: This parameter specifies the maximum queue depth for the ipcom_syslog() logging facility

IPCOM_SYSLOGD_LOG_FILE.summary: Log file for IPCOM system logging.
IPCOM_SYSLOGD_LOG_FILE.description: This parameter specifies a log file for IPCOM system logging. To disable logging, set the value to NULL.

IPNET_SOCK_ANON_PORT_MIN.description: Defines the lowest port number used as an ephemeral port number.

IPNET_SOCK_ANON_PORT_MAX.description: Defines the highest port number used as an ephemeral port number.

IPNET_SOCK_DEFAULT_SEND_BUFSIZE.description: The default size of the socket send buffer. The value must be greater than 2000.

IPNET_SOCK_DEFAULT_RECV_BUFSIZE.description: The default size of the socket receive buffer. The value must be greater than 2000.

IPNET_SOCK_ADDR_NOTIFY.description: Set to >0 to get notification on sockets bound to an address that has just been removed

IPNET_SOCK_ASSIGN_RANDOM.summary: Pseudo-random assignment of new sockets to stack instances
IPNET_SOCK_ASSIGN_RANDOM.description: Use "yes" or "no". When this parameter is "no", new sockets are always assigned to the primary network stack instance (tNet0). When this parameter is "yes", each new sockets is assigned pseudo-randomly to one of the network stack instances.

IPNET_ROUTE_MAX_CLONE_COUNT.description: Defines the maximum number of cloned route entries that might be present at any time. Most common usage of cloned routes are ARP and NDP entries.

IPNET_ROUTE_NEIGH_STALE_CORRECT.summary: More-correct but more-expensive handling of STALE state
IPNET_ROUTE_NEIGH_STALE_CORRECT.description: Ensures that even when sent to only by non-primary stack instances, a neighbor in STALE state globally transitions to DELAY state when any stack instance sends to the neighbor. This correct behavior can prevent brief interruption in traffic to the neighbor in some cases, but is not absolutely necessary and does impose additional CPU load on the primary stack instance. Use "yes" or "no".

IPNET_ROUTE_NEIGH_RATE_PERIOD.description: This parameter defines the rate limit period for the newly created neighbor entries in milliseconds.

IPNET_ROUTE_NEIGH_RATE_LIMIT.description: This parameter defines the limit of new neighbor entries that can be created in one neighbor rate limit period. The system cannot create new neighbors once this limit is reached. The default value is 0 which indicates that there is no maximum limit. A positive value is the limit number. Generally, this value is less than IPNET_ROUTE_MAX_CLONE_COUNT.

NETBUF_LEADING_CLSPACE_DRV.summary: Leading pad space for END pool clusters
NETBUF_LEADING_CLSPACE_DRV.description: Leading cluster pad space to add for network pools with only one cluster size, where that cluster size is at least 1500 bytes. The pad space is added to decrease the expense of prefixing additional headers to packets received from an END. The value chosen should generally be a multiple of the cache line size.

NET_JOB_NUM_CFG.description: This parameter specifies the maximum number of network jobs, netJobNum.

NET_TASK_DEFAULT_PRIORITY.description: This parameter specifies the default priority for the daemon task.

NET_TASK_PRIORITIES.description: This parameter specifies the task priorities for each network daemon. The format is "0,50;1,51", which means the priority for network daemon 0 is 50 and the priority for network daemon 1 is 51. When any error (invalid format or value) happens, the part of the parameter string after the error is ignored. If not specified, a network daemon's priority is set to                         NET_TASK_DEFAULT_PRIORITY. The default value of this                         parameter is "", which means that                         NET_TASK_DEFAULT_PRIORITY is the priority assigned to                         all network tasks.

NET_TASK_OPTIONS.description: This parameter specifies the taskSpawn options for the daemon.

NET_TASK_STACKSIZE.description: This parameter specifies the daemon stack size.

NUM_NET_DAEMONS.description: This parameter specifies the number of network daemon job queues to create. A value of zero means 1 for uniprocessor builds or, for SMP builds, the number of CPUs. Any other value is treated literally.

NET_DAEMONS_CPU_AFFINITY.summary: Default CPU affinity setting for network daemon tasks
NET_DAEMONS_CPU_AFFINITY.description: This parameter sets the default CPU affinity for network tasks in SMP builds. This parameter has no meaning for uniprocessor builds. If this parameter is set to TRUE, each network daemon number N is given (by default) affinity to CPU number N (when CPU N is configured). When this parameter is set to FALSE, network tasks are given no CPU affinity by default. You can override this parameter for specific network tasks using the NET_DAEMONS_CPU_AFFINITIES parameter.

NET_DAEMONS_CPU_AFFINITIES.description: This parameter configures the CPU affinity of each network daemon. This parameter overrides the default setting from NET_DAEMONS_CPU_AFFINITY. The format is "0,1;1,2", which means network daemon 0 is assigned to CPU 1, and network daemon 1 is assigned to CPU 2. If any error (invalid format or value) is encountered, the part of the parameter string after the error is ignored. For any network task not assigned by this parameter, the default setting from NET_DAEMONS_CPU_AFFINITY is used. The default value of this parameter is "", which means all network tasks use the NET_DAEMONS_CPU_AFFINITY setting.

NETDRV_OPTIONS.description: Options passed to netDrvEx() to initialize the netDrv driver code. Currently, there is only one option bit defined: NETDRV_CHDIR_REMOTE_CHECK -- When changing to a directory accessed via a netDrv device, or changing directory within a netDrv device, perform an actual check of the remote directory's existence via FTP or RSH.  Without this flag,                    no such check is made.

FTP6_REPLYTIMEOUT.description: value specifies timeout in sec, while waiting for ftp reply from server

FTP_TRANSIENT_MAX_RETRY_COUNT.summary: FTP Transient response maximum retry limit
FTP_TRANSIENT_MAX_RETRY_COUNT.description: Maximum number of retries when FTP_TRANSIENT response encountered

FTP_TRANSIENT_RETRY_INTERVAL.summary: Time delay between retries after FTP_TRANSIENT encountered
FTP_TRANSIENT_RETRY_INTERVAL.description: The time interval (in clock ticks) between reissuing a command

FTP_TRANSIENT_FATAL.description: Should a transient response be retried or aborted

FTP_DEBUG_OPTIONS.description: Enable various debugging facilities within ftpLib

FTP_TIMEOUT.description: Specifies timeout in sec, while waiting for FTP reply from server

IP_MAX_UNITS.description: Maximum number of interfaces attached to IP layer. It remains here for backward compatibility since BSPs still using it. The IPNet stack does not use this parameter.

MIB2IF_TRAP_RTN.description: Pointer to a user-supplied SNMP trap generator

MIB2IF_TRAP_ARG.summary: Pointer to user trap generator argument
MIB2IF_TRAP_ARG.description: Pointer to a user-supplied SNMP trap generator argument

MIB2IF_LONG_COUNTERS.description: Enable or disable 64-bit counters from RFC 2233

MIB2IP_MAX_ROUTE_TBL_SIZE.description: Default size of the MIB-II route table cache

MIB2SYS_OID_LEN.description: Number of elements in MIB-2 ObjectId

RSH_STDERR_SETUP_TIMEOUT.description: Time limit for optional rcmd() stderr connection

REM_NUM_CONN_RETRIALS.description: Number of times to retry if connect fails.

RLOGIN_MAXCLIENTS.description: value specifies default limit for simultaneous sessions

RLOGIN_CLIENT_NUMBERS.description: Number of rlogin client to be approved to create

SEC_VAULT_FILE_ROOT.description: Top directory where the VxWorks vault directory structure shall be created. For backwards compatibility reasons the default value is set to /ram. In deployed systems the key db file root would be set to a directory in a persistent file system, for example, "/flash".

SEC_VAULT_KEY_ENCRYPTING_PW.description: Password used to encrypt keys in the secrets repository and key store, when INCLUDE_SEC_VAULT_KEP_OBFUSCATOR is used as the KEP backend. This parameter should be set to a random string of at least 40 characters, containing both lower and upper case, numbers and special characters. SEC_VAULT_KEY_ENCRYPTING_PW has no default value on purpose. This will force each customer to set a unique value.

TIMEZONE_ENV_VAR.description: This parameter sets the time zone environment variable used for the default time zone. It supports the C standard library format (TIMEZONE) or the POSIX format (TZ). The TIMEZONE format is for example TIMEZONE=:EST:EDT:-0500:031502-0:110802-0 where EST is 5 hours and 00 minutes behind UTC. EDT begins on the first Sunday before (-0) 15 March (0315) at 02:00 (02). EDT ends on the first Sunday before (-0) 8 November (1108) at 02:00 (02). The TZ format is for example TZ=CST6CDT,M3.2.0/02,M11.1.0/02 where CST is 6 hours behind UTC. CDT begins on the second (.2) Sunday (.0) in March (,M3) at 2:00 AM (/02). CDT ends on the first (.1) Sunday (.0) in November (,M11) at 2:00 AM (/02).

UMASK_DEFAULT.description: The parameter specifies the default value of the file mode creation mask.

MQ_HASH_SIZE.summary: POSIX message queue hash table size
MQ_HASH_SIZE.description: This parameter sets the size for the POSIX message queue hash table size. By default it is set to zero.

KERN_PTHREAD_STACK_SIZE_DEFAULT.summary: Default stack size for POSIX pthreads in kernel
KERN_PTHREAD_STACK_SIZE_DEFAULT.description: This parameter sets the default stack size in bytes used for POSIX pthreads created in the kernel for which a stack size is not specified using a pthread_attr_t parameter.

NUM_SIGNAL_QUEUES.description: This parameter sets the maximum number of queued signals in the kernel. The default is 16.

TIMER_SETTIME_RESTRICTED.description: This parameter specifies if calling timer_settime() with TIME_ABSTIME and the real-time clock should be prohibited. The default is to allow such call.

HIGH_RES_POSIX_CLOCK.description: Use the native timer frequency for CLOCK_REALTIME instead of system ticks. This option is not supported on simulators and has no effect.

POSIX_CLOCK_TIMER.summary: Timer used with the high resolution POSIX clock
POSIX_CLOCK_TIMER.description: This parameter specifies the timer to use in association with HIGH_RES_POSIX_CLOCK. If left NULL, the next available timer with the highest frequency is used.

BOOT_LINE_SIZE.description: This parameter specifies the boot line size in bytes.

BOOT_LINE_ADRS.description: This parameter specifies the boot line (memory region) address.

BOOT_LINE_OFFSET.description: This parameter specifies the boot line offset.

ROOT_STACK_SIZE.description: This parameter defines the root task stack size in bytes.

INT_LOCK_LEVEL.description: This parameter defines the interrupt lock level.

TASK_USER_EXC_STACK_SIZE.description: This parameter defines the size (in bytes) of the exception stack for the user tasks.

TASK_KERNEL_EXC_STACK_SIZE.description: This parameter defines the size of the exception stack for kernel tasks.

TASK_USER_EXC_STACK_OVERFLOW_SIZE.summary: User task exception stack overflow protection size
TASK_USER_EXC_STACK_OVERFLOW_SIZE.description: This parameter defines the size (in bytes) of the protected area at the end of the task exception stack. It should be non-negative, and a multiple of the page size.

TASK_USER_EXEC_STACK_OVERFLOW_SIZE.summary: User task execution stack overflow protection size
TASK_USER_EXEC_STACK_OVERFLOW_SIZE.description: This parameter defines the size (in bytes) of the protected area at the end of the task execution stack. It should be non-negative, and a multiple of the page size.

TASK_USER_EXEC_STACK_UNDERFLOW_SIZE.summary: User task execution stack underflow protection size
TASK_USER_EXEC_STACK_UNDERFLOW_SIZE.description: This parameter defines the size (in bytes) of the protected area at the start of the task execution stack. It should be non-negative, and a multiple of the page size.

TASK_KERNEL_EXEC_STACK_OVERFLOW_SIZE.summary: Kernel task execution stack overflow protection size
TASK_KERNEL_EXEC_STACK_OVERFLOW_SIZE.description: This parameter defines the size (in bytes) of the protected area at the end of the task execution stack. It should be non-negative, and a multiple of the page size.

TASK_KERNEL_EXEC_STACK_UNDERFLOW_SIZE.summary: Kernel task execution stack underflow protection size
TASK_KERNEL_EXEC_STACK_UNDERFLOW_SIZE.description: This parameter defines the size (in bytes) of the protected area at the start of the task execution stack. It should be non-negative, and a multiple of the page size.

TASK_KERNEL_EXC_STACK_OVERFLOW_SIZE.summary: Kernel task exception stack overflow protection size
TASK_KERNEL_EXC_STACK_OVERFLOW_SIZE.description: This parameter defines the size (in bytes) of the protected area at the end of the task exception stack. It includes idle tasks as well, in SMP. It should be non-negative, and a multiple of the page size. By default this parameter is zero, except when using the SECURE VIP profile, in which case it is 4096.

TASK_PRIORITY_SET_COMPATIBLE.summary: Enable compatible mode for task priority setting
TASK_PRIORITY_SET_COMPATIBLE.description: This configuration parameter is used to enable the backward compatible (but incorrect) way of handling task priority changes. When set to TRUE, a running task may be preempted when its priority is lowered to a level at which other ready tasks are waiting. This configuration option will be removed in a future release.

WIND_JOBS_MAX.description: This parameter sets the kernel work queue size (number of entries). It must be a power of 2. If it is set to a value below 64, it can cause work queue panics in the system.

VX_GLOBAL_NO_STACK_FILL.summary: Disable stack fill on all tasks
VX_GLOBAL_NO_STACK_FILL.description: This parameter is used to disable the stack fill. When set to TRUE, stack fill is disabled.

MAX_REBOOT_HOOKS.description: This parameter sets the maximum number of reboot hooks that can be set. The default value is 5.

ENV_VAR_USE_HOOKS.summary: Environment variable task create/delete hook installation
ENV_VAR_USE_HOOKS.description: This parameter controls installHooks. If installHooks is TRUE, task create and delete hooks are installed that can optionally create and destroy private environments for the task being created or destroyed, depending on the state of VX_PRIVATE_ENV in the task options word. If installHooks is FALSE and a task requires a private environment, the application must create and destroy the private environment using envPrivateCreate( ) and envPrivateDestroy( ).

MAX_ISR_JOBS.summary: Maximum number of jobs posted from ISR level
MAX_ISR_JOBS.description: This parameter defines the maximum number of jobs that can be posted to tExcTask from the interrupt service routine (ISR) level. In most applications, the default value is sufficient to handle the jobs posted from the ISR level. If the number of jobs posted exceeds MAX_ISR_JOBS, an overflow error occurs. Before increasing the value of MAX_ISR_JOBS, Wind River recommends that you review the ISRs that are posting jobs to ensure the ISR is not improperly posting more jobs than the system can handle at any one time.

EXC_TASK_PRIORITY.description: This parameter specifies the priority for the Exception task. Changing this parameter without understanding the exact implications of your change can result in system instability. The default is zero.

JOB_TASK_STACK_SIZE.description: This parameter specifies the job task stack size.

JOB_TASK_PRIORITY.description: This parameter specifies the priority for the job task. Changing this parameter without understanding the exact implications of your change can result in system instability. The default is zero.

FUNCPTR_OBJ_MEMALLOC_RTN.description: This parameter specifies the function pointer to the objMemAllocRtn() function.

FUNCPTR_OBJ_MEMFREE_RTN.description: This parameter specifies the function pointer to the objMemFreeRtn() function.

OBJ_MEM_POOL_ID.description: This parameter specifies the object memory pool ID.

OBJ_LIBRARY_OPTIONS.summary: Default option for the object library
OBJ_LIBRARY_OPTIONS.description: This parameter specifies global options for the object library.

VXEVENTS_OPTIONS.description: This parameter specifies the configuration for VxWorks events. For a list of support options and a more detailed description, see the reference information for eventLib.

SEM_RW_MAX_CONCURRENT_READERS.summary: Maximum number of concurrent RW semaphore readers
SEM_RW_MAX_CONCURRENT_READERS.description: This parameter sets the maximum number of concurrent RW semaphore readers.

VX_MAX_TASK_CREATE_RTNS.description: This parameter specifies the size of the task create and delete hook tables. By default, it is set to 40.

MEM_PART_DEFAULT_OPTIONS.description: This component provides the default memory partition options when the full featured memory allocator is present.

KERNEL_PROXIMITY_HEAP_SIZE.description: This parameter specifies the kernel proximity heap size.

KERNEL_COMMON_HEAP_INIT_SIZE.description: This parameter specifies the initial size of the heap. It should not be set to a value larger than the available largest physically contiguous block of RAM. Take into account the size of a page and other bookkeeping information, which reduces the actual maximum value that can be used with this parameter.

KERNEL_COMMON_HEAP_INCR_SIZE.description: This parameter helps support auto-growth of the kernel common heap. When the current heap content cannot satisfy the requested allocation, the operating system automatically adds more memory which is allocated from the kernel virtual memory pool region and the global RAM pool. Growth is subject to available free RAM in the pool. The amount of heap growth is a multiple of this parameter. Setting this parameter to zero disables auto-growth.

POSIX_SIGNAL_MODE.description: If this parameter is set to TRUE, signals resulting from hardware exceptions will be handled according to the POSIX 1003.1 specification. When the SA_SIGINFO flag is set for sigaction(), the POSIX defined signal subcode and the exception vector number will be set in the siginfo_t structure (si_code and si_value, respectively). Otherwise, a backward compatible mode, that always sets SI_SYNC to signal subcode, will be used.

EDR_PM_ARENA.description: By default, the error detection and reporting persistent memory arena is defined by the function 'pmDefaultArena'. It can be over-ridden in usrPmInit.c if necessary, for example, to place the default PM arena in non-volatile memory for a specific BSP.

PM_RESERVED_MEM.description: This parameter sets the size of the persistent memory region (in bytes). By default, it is set to six pages of memory.

EDR_ERRLOG_SIZE.description: This parameter sets the size of the persistent memory area reserved for error records (in bytes). By default, it is set to one-half of the persistent memory available.

EDR_RECORD_SIZE.description: This parameter is used to change the default size (in bytes) of error records. Note that, for performance reasons, all records are the same size.

POSIX_PTHREAD_RR_TIMESLICE.summary: User POSIX thread time slice in ticks
POSIX_PTHREAD_RR_TIMESLICE.description: This parameter can be used to configure the default time slicing interval for pthreads started with the SCHED_RR policy. To modify the time slice at run time, call kernelTimeSlice() with a different time slice value. The new time slice value only affects pthreads created after the kernelTimeSlice() call.

RTP_PTHREAD_STACK_SIZE_DEFAULT.summary: Default stack size for POSIX pthreads in non-kernel RTPs
RTP_PTHREAD_STACK_SIZE_DEFAULT.description: This parameter sets the default stack size in bytes used for POSIX pthreads created in non-kernel RTPs for which a stack size is not specified using either a pthread_attr_t parameter, or the PTHREAD_STACK_SIZE_DEFAULT environment variable.

VX_NATIVE_SCHED_CONSTANT_RDY_Q.description: (Obsoleted) This parameter is replaced by VX_TRAD_SCHED_CONSTANT_RDY_Q.

VX_TRAD_SCHED_CONSTANT_RDY_Q.description: The traditional scheduler requires this parameter to be set to TRUE, which is the default.

MAX_LOG_MSGS.description: This parameter specifies the maximum number of queued messages. The default value is 50.

LOG_TASK_PRIORITY.description: This parameter defines the priority with which the logging task, tLogTask, is spawned. The default value is zero.

NUM_EARLY_SYSLOG_MSGS.summary: Maximum number of early messages for syslog
NUM_EARLY_SYSLOG_MSGS.description: This parameter defines the number of messages that can be logged before the logging facility is initialized. The default value is zero.

HOST_NAME_DEFAULT.summary: Default host name for the boot line
HOST_NAME_DEFAULT.description: This parameter specifies the default value for the host name field of the VxWorks boot line.

TARGET_NAME_DEFAULT.summary: Default target name for the boot line
TARGET_NAME_DEFAULT.description: This parameter specifies the default value for the target name field of the VxWorks boot line (tn).

HOST_USER_DEFAULT.summary: Default host user for the boot line
HOST_USER_DEFAULT.description: This parameter specifies the default value for the host user field of the VxWorks boot line (u).

HOST_PASSWORD_DEFAULT.summary: Default host password for the boot line
HOST_PASSWORD_DEFAULT.description: This parameter specifies the default value for the host password field of the VxWorks boot line.

SCRIPT_DEFAULT.summary: Default script for the boot line
SCRIPT_DEFAULT.description: This parameter specifies the default value for the script field of the VxWorks boot line (s).

OTHER_DEFAULT.summary: Default other field for the boot line
OTHER_DEFAULT.description: This parameter specifies the default value for the other field of the VxWorks boot line (o).

INTERRUPT_STACK_OVERFLOW_SIZE.description: This parameter defines the size (in bytes) of the protected area at the end of the interrupt stack. It should be non-negative, and a multiple of the page size.

INTERRUPT_STACK_UNDERFLOW_SIZE.description: This parameter defines the size (in bytes) of the protected area at the start of the interrupt stack. It should be non-negative, and a multiple of the page size.

DKM_TLS_SIZE.description: This parameter specifies the size of the extra thread local storage (TLS) block that is reserved for allocating thread local variables in downloadable kernel modules (DKMs).

DKM_TLS_MAX_ALIGNMENT.description: This parameter specifies the maximum alignment supported for thread local variables in downloadable kernel modules (DKMs).

RANDOM_TASK_SWITCH_ROUNDS.summary: Number of times the task switch hook shall add entropy
RANDOM_TASK_SWITCH_ROUNDS.description: The parameter specifies the number of times the task switch hook shall call the random number lib in order to add entropy. 0 means that the task switch hook will make calls indefinitely. Once the configured number of calls have been made, the task switch hook will be removed.

RANDOM_INTERRUPT_ROUNDS.summary: Number of times the interrupt handler shall add entropy
RANDOM_INTERRUPT_ROUNDS.description: The parameter specifies the number of times the interrupt handler shall call the random number lib in order to add entropy. 0 means that the interrupt handler will make calls indefinitely. Once the configured number of calls has been reached no more calls will be made.

USER_I_MMU_ENABLE.description: This parameter enables the instruction MMU.

USER_D_MMU_ENABLE.description: This parameter enables the data MMU.

MAX_POWER_OFF_HOOKS.summary: Maximum number of power off hooks
MAX_POWER_OFF_HOOKS.description: This parameter sets the maximum number of power off hooks that can be set. The default value is 5.

VX_SMP_NUM_CPUS.summary: Number of CPUs to be enabled for SMP
VX_SMP_NUM_CPUS.description: This parameter sets the number of CPUs that you wish to enable for symmetric multiprocessing (SMP). This value must be greater than zero.

ENABLE_ALL_CPUS.summary: Enable all configured CPUs for SMP
ENABLE_ALL_CPUS.description: This parameter enables all configured CPUs for symmetric multiprocessing (SMP).

VX_ENABLE_CPU_TIMEOUT.summary: Timeout for enabling additional CPUs in SMP

VX_SMP_CPU_EXPLICIT_RESERVE.summary: SMP CPUs to be excluded from indiscriminate reservation
VX_SMP_CPU_EXPLICIT_RESERVE.description: This parameter specifies the CPUs that are excluded from the indiscriminate reservation pool. They are not, however, prevented from being explicitly reserved.

DEBUG_KWRITE_USR_RTN.description: This configuration parameter defines the output function for use with kprintf( ) and kputs( ).

TARGET_HOSTNAME_DEFAULT.description: This parameter provides a default hostname for the target, which is used if the target name is not available from the boot parameters. You can retrieve the target hostname using the gethostname() function.

LOCAL_MEM_LOCAL_ADRS.description: This parameter specifies the the start of the on-board memory area.

LOCAL_MEM_PHYS_ADRS.description: Base physical address. For LPAE, alignment of address must be 2MB.

VEC_BASE_ADRS.description: This parameter specifies the vector base address.

EXC_MSG_ADRS.description: This parameter specifies the exception message start address.

EXC_MSG_OFFSET.description: This parameter specifies the exception message offset.

EXC_MSG_SIZE.description: This parameter specifies the exception message size.

ROM_WARM_ADRS.description: This parameter specifies the warm boot address.

STACK_SAVE.description: This parameter defines the number of bytes on the stack to reserve for ROM code.

RAM_LOW_ADRS.description: This parameter specifies the address at which to load VxWorks.

KERNEL_LOAD_ADRS.description: This parameter defines the address for the VxWorks kernel to load the uVxWorks image.

DEBUG_AGENT_TASK_PRIORITY.summary: Priority of Application Mode Agent tasks
DEBUG_AGENT_TASK_PRIORITY.description: All Application Mode Agent tasks will be spawned with this priority. 49 is a sensible default.

DEBUG_AGENT_CONFIG.description: Options for Debug Agent configuration. Format is "-g <port> -s <protocol>:<ipAddr>:<port>". Option -g is to start GDB Remote Serial Protocol server at the specified TCP port. For option -s, Default "<protocol>" is TCP. Default "<ipAddr>" is empty meaning agent listens on every interfaces. Default "<port>" is 1534. For example setting "-s TCP::5656" modifies default port to use port 5656.

DEBUG_AGENT_MEM_SIZE.description: tcf open source code alloc memory from this partition

OPENSSL_HOME.description: This parameter specifies the home directory for OpenSSL. By default, it is "/ram/openssl".

OPENSSL_CONF.description: This parameter sets the name of the OpenSSL configuration file. By default, it is OPENSSL_HOME "/openssl.cnf".

ERF_MAX_USR_CATEGORIES.summary: Maximum number of ERF user categories
ERF_MAX_USR_CATEGORIES.description: Sets the maximum number of user categories

ERF_MAX_USR_TYPES.summary: Maximum number of ERF user types
ERF_MAX_USR_TYPES.description: Sets the maximum number of user types.

ERF_TASK_STACK_SIZE.description: Defines the initial task stack size for the event reporting framework. Its default value is 4096.

ERF_MAX_EVENT_QUEUE_SIZE.description: The size of ERF event queue.

ERF_EVENT_TASK_OPTIONS.description: The options of ERF event task

RAM_DISK_BLK_SIZE.description: This parameter specifies the RAM disk block size.

RAM_DISK_SIZE.description: This parameter specifies the amount of RAM (in bytes) allocated for the RAM disk.

RAM_DISK_DEV_NAME.description: This parameter sets the default RAM disk device name.

FS_ORIGIN_DEVICE_NAME.summary: VxWorks file system IOS device name
FS_ORIGIN_DEVICE_NAME.description: Sets the default VxWorks file system IOS device name.

FS_MOUNT_VALIDATE_TIMEOUT.description: Sets the maximum time to wait (in seconds) for a file system IOS device to be mounted. A value of 0 means no waiting.

FS_TARGET_DEVICE_NAME.summary: File system IOS device name used for renamed devices
FS_TARGET_DEVICE_NAME.description: Sets the default file system IOS device name used for renamed devices.

END_NET_JOB_INIT_STRING.description: This string is used in a multi-threaded stack configuration to specify which network task work queue should be used by a given END interface (can be overridden at runtime using the muxEndQnumSet() API)

END_POLL_STATS_ROUTINE_HOOK.description: Function pointer for reading END driver stats

MUX_L2_NUM_PORTS_CFG.description: This parameter specifies the maximum number of physical ports available to the target.

MUX_L2_MAX_VLANS_CFG.description: This parameters specifies the maximum number of 802.1Q virtual LANs supported on the target.

NFS2_CLIENT_CACHE_DEFAULT_NUM_LINES.description: The NFS client implementation uses a persistent cache, which is structured as a multi-line buffer cache. This parameter configures the default number of lines in the NFS v2 client cache. The default value is 16. You can decrease this value to as low as 1, or increase it. You can modify the number of cache lines, either at build time or at run time. To configure the cache at run time, call the function usrNfs2CacheInit( ): usrNfs2CacheInit (UINT32 numLines, UINT32 lineSize, UINT32 options);

NFS2_CLIENT_CACHE_DEFAULT_LINE_SIZE.summary: Default number of bytes in the cache line
NFS2_CLIENT_CACHE_DEFAULT_LINE_SIZE.description: The NFS client implementation uses a persistent cache, which is structured as a multi-line buffer cache. The cache line size must be a power of two. This parameter configures the default size of the NFS v2 client cache line. The default value for this is 16384 (16 KB). When combined with the default number of cache lines, this yields a default cache size of 256 KB. You can modify the cache line size, either at build time or at run time.
